context.text: Yes, but may I interrupt there.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I don't see why under your theory that the State must have a navigational purpose.

context.text: Why couldn't the State under your theory decide, as Justice O'Connor suggested, they would like a little more territory and if they found an area in which there is no navigational problem and no environmental problem, would just build a jetty out for 2 miles for the express and sole purpose of getting more territory.

context.speaker: John G. Gissberg
context.text: Well, I think actually under what this Court may have said, that they can do that.

context.speaker: John G. Gissberg
context.text: --Justice White, I think if the Government would recognize that maybe for an instant that becomes our property then we can clearly enter into an agreement with it, but that would take a fundamental step for them to take that they haven't taken yet.

context.speaker: John G. Gissberg
context.text: So we would not enter into an agreement about something that they won't let us own.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Do you claim that the agreement would not be a valid agreement and a binding alienation, in light of your answer to Justice Kennedy?

context.speaker: John G. Gissberg
context.text: I think that it would be.

context.speaker: John G. Gissberg
context.text: We would have to interpret the rights to the 730 acres in one way, even though they would disagree.

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: John G. Gissberg
context.text: We would have to interpret the rights to the 730 acres in one way, even though they would disagree.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So all you are really saying is, we just wouldn't do it unless they will salve our lust for title by agreeing that we get it for at least an instant, we simply wouldn't agree, but you admit you could agree and that the answer to Justice White's question is, it is not the end of the matter, and Nome could end up building its causeway anyway after we had agreed voluntarily to alienate what we claim we had.

context.text: Well, we sure wouldn't do it voluntarily.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Respondent, Thompson/Center Arms, manufactures a pistol called the Contender and for a brief period also manufactured a kit that could be used to convert the pistol either to a carbine riffle with a 21-inch barrel or if the pistol barrel was left on to a short-barreled riffle with a 10-inch barrel.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Unlike the pistol or the longer riffle, a sp-called short-barreled riffle is regulated under the National Firearms Act with the consequence that making such riffle is a taxable act.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We granted certiorari in this case to resolve a conflict between the Circuits about whether a short-barreled riffle actually must be assembled in order to be made and, hence, for that act to be taxable within the meaning of the statute.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In an opinion filed today with the Clerk of the Court and in which the Chief Justice and Justice O'Connor join, we conclude that it need not be assembled and that some disassembled aggregations of parts are included in Congress' definition.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We conclude that an aggregation of parts that would serve no useful purpose except the assembly of a regulated firearm would constitute the making of a firearm within the meaning of the Act.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We find Congress' language ambiguous however, as to those aggregations of parts that would have utility in permitting to assemble of unregulated firearms as in the case before us.

United States v. Thompson/Center Arms Co.speaker: Justice Souter

United States v. Thompson/Center Arms Co.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 08, 1992

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: We find Congress' language ambiguous however, as to those aggregations of parts that would have utility in permitting to assemble of unregulated firearms as in the case before us.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Although the case arises in a civil setting, the statute has criminal consequences and we, therefore, apply the rule of lenity to conclude that in packaging, the pistol and conversion kit together, Thompson/Center had not made a short-barreled riffle within the meaning of the Act.
